item.title: Letter From Europe: If Scotland Leaves, Will the Union Jack Still Wave?
item.description: The possible departure of Scotland from Britain raises all kinds of esoteric questions about the United Kingdom’s banner.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: The Union Jack combines the colors of the three patron saints of England, Scotland and Ireland.

item.title: Karzai Cousin Killed by Suicide Bomber in Afghanistan
item.description: Hashmat Khalil Karzai, a major player in the Afghan presidential election, was killed as he greeted well-wishers at this home in Kandahar.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Israel Destroys Home of a Top Political Leader of Hamas
item.description: Airstrikes also destroyed offices of the movement’s radio and television station a day after attacks on both sides punctured a humanitarian halt to hostilities.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A Palestinian displays a portrait of the deputy chief of the Hamas movement, Ismail Haniya, in the rubble of his home in Gaza.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Don’t Fear Jihadists Returning From Syria
item.description: Contrary to what many counterterrorism experts believe, ISIS has so far shown no interest in Western targets.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CHAMS EDDINE ZAOUGUI and PIETER VAN OSTAEYEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At McDonald’s Outlets in China, Patrons Ask Where’s the Meat?
item.description: On Tuesday, meat shortages were being reported in many of the more than 2,000 McDonald’s outlets in China following a supplier’s recall for its China-made products.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A notice to customers at a McDonald's restaurant in Beijing apologizing for the limited menu and saying efforts are underway to restore products.

item.title: China Says Zhou Yongkang, Former Security Chief, Is Under Investigation
item.description: Mr. Zhou, who retired from the Politburo Standing Committee in late 2012, is the most senior Communist Party figure ever to face a formal graft inquiry.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Former Public Security Minister, Zhou Yongkang, at the China's National Congress meeting in 2007.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: France Remembers World War I
item.description: A surge of interest in World War I hasn’t set off any new debate. Historians agree: This is a very consensual centennial.
item.dc:creator: By SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: European Officials Weigh Tougher Sanctions on Moscow
item.description: After an agreement with the United States to sharply escalate sanctions, the measures worried some companies that have major investments in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin attended a wreath-laying ceremony on Sunday in Severomorsk, Russia.

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographing on the Ground in Gaza
item.description: Sergey Ponomarev has encountered a war routine in Gaza, documenting the destruction and casualties of the latest conflict.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohammed Shinbary comforted his daughter Mahasin, 7, who was injured in an Israeli airstrike at the United Nation school in Beit Hanoun. He went to see her in the hospital in Beit Lahiya. July 24, 2014.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Officials, Cutting Corners, Add 4 of Them to Running Track
item.description: Officials in northeastern China who built a running track with four neat right-angle corners said they were trying to please their leaders.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Aviation Authorities Warn of Severe Flight Delays in Eastern China
item.description: The authorities announced that air traffic capacity would be reduced by as much as 75 percent on Tuesday in Shanghai. Several other eastern Chinese cities will also be affected.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Chinese airports already had some of world's worst records for on-time departures.

item.title: Chinese Authorities Investigate Pegasus, a Unit of Edelman
item.description: Political observers said the move could be linked to a wider inquiry into corruption at the state TV network CCTV, and to the investigation of senior security officials.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Muslims Seek American’s Release
item.description: Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent incarcerated in Tehran for nearly three years, spent his 31st birthday in prison on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Grim Discoveries in Baghdad
item.description: The police on Monday said that they had found 17 bullet-riddled bodies in different areas of Baghdad and that other attacks killed 10 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Tracking of Arms Faulted
item.description: The United States has failed to effectively track many of the more than 465,000 light weapons it has supplied to Afghanistan, creating the risk that machine guns and other small arms could fall into insurgent hands.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Short Staff Tries to Cope With Ebola
item.description: As an outbreak worsened, a pay dispute with nurses left a short staff able to care primarily for just the sickest patients who had a chance of surviving.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY

item.title: Tunnels Lead Right to the Heart of Israeli Fear
item.description: The sophistication and extent of the underground passages used by Hamas to infiltrate Israel from Gaza has stiffened Israeli resolve to destroy them.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Oshik Azulai, the deputy commander of the Israeli military’s Southern Gaza Division, inside a tunnel that stretches most of a mile from Gaza into Israel, ending near Kibbutz Ein Hashlosha.

item.title: Venezuelan Officers Linked to Colombian Cocaine Traffickers
item.description: The head of Venezuelan military intelligence was on the payroll of a Colombian drug lord, invested money in drug shipments and coordinated the shipment of cocaine, according to prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Venezuelan Presidential Office, via AFP-Getty Images
item.media:description: Hugo Carvajal, left, with President Nicolás Maduro on Monday. An American indictment says Mr. Carvajal protected a drug lord and invested in cocaine shipments.

item.title: U.S. and Europe Set to Toughen Russia Sanctions
item.description: A package targeting Russia’s financial, energy and defense sectors was driven by the conclusion that Moscow has taken a more direct role in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, said that while Moscow clearly did not welcome the measures, it had no plans to impose sanctions on Europe in response.

item.title: Boko Haram Targets Political Figures in String of Attacks
item.description: The terrorist group has attacked or kidnapped prominent citizens in Cameroon and Nigeria, and has committed a series of suicide bombings that have killed at least 11 over two days.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Israeli Leader Sees No Quick End to Gaza War
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, told citizens to prepare themselves for a prolonged conflict after an informal lull was shattered.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: In Ferry Deaths, a South Korean Tycoon’s Downfall
item.description: The sinking of the ferry Sewol killed 304 passengers and exposed a web of questionable business practices by Yoo Byung-eun, who was found dead in June.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN, MARTIN FACKLER, ALISON LEIGH COWAN and SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers and members of the news media at the scene where the body of Yoo Byung-eun was discovered.

item.title: Fuel Depot Fire Endangers Civilians in Libya
item.description: Two storage tanks are ablaze in the fire, which was started by militias fighting for control of the airport in Tripoli.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By OSAMA AL-FITORY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Mandalay Journal: Where Ancient Burmese Beauty Balm Competes With Modern Cosmetics
item.description: Thanakha, a paste long prized in Myanmar for its sunblock and aesthetic qualities, is facing a challenge from multinational cosmetic corporations.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Girls and women in Myanmar paint golden circles on their cheeks made from the pulverized bark of thanakha trees

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Tested Cruise Missile, Violating Treaty
item.description: The United States has concluded that Russia violated a landmark arms control treaty by testing a prohibited ground-launched cruise missile, according to senior American officials.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
